review.title: Unfolding Latent Tree Structures using 4th Order Tensors
review.abstract: Discovering the latent structure from many observed variables is an important yet challenging learning task. Existing approaches for discovering latent structures often require the unknown number of hidden states as an input. In this paper, we propose a quartet based approach which is \emph{agnostic} to this number. The key contribution is a novel rank characterization of the tensor associated with the marginal distribution of a quartet. This characterization allows us to design a \emph{nuclear norm} based test for resolving quartet relations. We then use the quartet test as a subroutine in a divide-and-conquer algorithm for recovering the latent tree structure. Under mild conditions, the algorithm is consistent and its error probability decays exponentially with increasing sample size. We demonstrate that the proposed approach compares favorably to alternatives. In a real world stock dataset, it also discovers meaningful groupings of variables, and produces a model that fits the data better.

metadata.title: Unfolding Latent Tree Structures using 4th Order Tensors

sections.heading: 2 Latent Tree Graphical Models
sections.text: In this paper, we focus on discrete latent variables, in which conditional independence structures are defined by trees. We assume that the observed variables, O = {X1,.., Xd}, are the leaves of the tree, and that they all have the same number of states, n. However, we also assume that the i.e. hidden variables, H = {Xd + 1,., Xd + dh}, have the same number of states, n. In addition, we use uppercase letters to name random variables (e.g., Xi) and lowercase letters of their instances (e.g., xi).Factorizing the distribution of all variables, X = O, in a latent tree model is a multipath table (tensor), P, with d + dh dimensions. sections.text: In this section, we first develop a test for resolving the latent relationship of a quartet when the number of hidden states is unknown. Our approach refers to information from the common probability table of a quartet, which represents a 4-way table or a 4-way tenor. Let us assume that the quartet relationship of 4 variables, X1, X2, X3 and X4, each has a 4-way structure. sections.heading: 3.3 Nuclear Norm Relaxation for the Rank Condition
sections.text: In practice, due to the sampling noise, all unfolding matrices A, B, and C would be nearly full, so the rank condition cannot be applied directly. To accomplish this, we design a test based on the relaxation of the rank condition by means of a nuclear standard. (10) This is the sum of all the individual values of a matrix (s) M. Instead of comparing the ranking order of A, B, and C, we look for the smallest nuclear standard and declare the latent structure that corresponds to it. sections.heading: 6 Experiments
sections.text: We compared our algorithm with representative algorithms: the Neighbor Joining Algorithm (NJ) (Saitou & Nei, 1987), a quartet-based algorithm by Anandkumar et al. (2011) (Spectral @ k), the Chow-Liu Neighbor Joining Algorithm (CLNJ) (Choi et al., 2011), and an algorithm by Harmeling & Williams (2010) (HW). NJ proceeds by recursively connecting two variables that are closest to an additive spacing called dij = 1 2 log det diagPi − log | detPij | + 12 log diagPj where "det" is determinant, "diag is a diagonalization operator, Pij denotes the common probability table P (Xi, Xj), and Pi and Pj the probability vector P (Xi) and P (Xj), respectively.

sections.heading: 6.1 Resolving Quartet Relations
sections.text: We compared our method with NJ and Spectral @ k in terms of their ability to restore the quartet relationship between four variables; we used quartet with three different configurations for the hidden states: (1) kH = 2 and kG = 4 (small difference); (2) kH = 2, kG = 8 (large difference); and (3) kH = 4, kG = 4 (no difference). In all cases, the states of the observed variables were fixed to n = 10. In all cases, we assumed independent PHG, but the identity of PXi | H and PXi | G, and interfered with the following formula P (a = i | b) = P (a = i | b) + ui, with all ui i.e. random variables drawn from uniform [0, µ] being best.

sections.heading: 6.2 Discovering Latent Tree Structure
sections.text: We used different tree topologies and sample sizes in this experiment. We created tree topologies by randomly splitting 16 observed variables recursively into two groups. Recursive splitting stops when there are only two nodes in a group. We introduced a hidden variable to join the two partitions in each recursion, and this results in a latent tree structure. The topology of the tree is controlled by a single partition parameter β, which controls the relative size of the first partition versus the second. If β is near 0 or 1, we get trees of distorted shape, with a long path of hidden variables. If β is near 0.5, the resulting latent trees are more balanced. In our experiments, we experimented with distorted latent trees β = 0.2 and balanced trees β = 0.5. We first create different random k between 2 and 8 for the hidden states, and then generate the probability models for each tree using the same scheme.

sections.heading: 6.3 Understanding Latent Relations between Stocks
sections.text: We applied our algorithm to discover a latent tree structure from a set of shares. Our goal is to understand how Xi share prices relate to each other. We acquired closing prices of 59 shares from 1984 to 2011 (from www.finance.yahoo.com), which provide us with 6,800 examples. Daily changes in each share price are discredited into 10 values, and we applied our algorithm to build a latent tree. A visualization of the tree topologies learned and groupings discovered are shown in Figure 6.We see nice groupings of stocks according to their industrial sectors. Companies related to petroleum, such as CVX (Chevron), XOM (Exxon Mobil), APA (Apache), COP (Cono-coPhillips), SLB (Schlumberger) and SUN (Sunoco), are grouped into a subtree. Pharmaceutical companies, such as MRK (Merck), PFE (Pfizer), BMY Mquiyer Bristol Squiyer (Lilb) are grouped into a subtree.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: The practical advantage of the new method is that we do not have to determine in advance the number of hidden states that are normally unknown in practice; the key idea is to consider the common probability tables of the quadruple variables as 4th order tensors and then use the spectral properties of the deployed tensors to design a quartet test. We offer conditions under which the algorithm is consistent and its error probability decreases exponentially with increasing sample size. In both simulated and real data sets, we have demonstrated the usefulness of our methods for discovering latent structures. While in this study we focus on the properties of the 4th order tensor and its various unfoldings, we believe that the properties of tensors and methods and algorithms from multilinear algebra will allow us to address many other problems arising from latent variable models.

sections.heading: 13 Statistical Guarantee for the Quartet Test
sections.text: Based on the concentration result for the nuclear standard in (11), we have the probability that the finite nuclear standard in the m samples deviates from its actual size: − − − − − − − − − A samples show the probability that the finite nuclear standard deviates from its actual size: − A samples show the probability that a single quartet test is faulty. − B samples now show the probability that a single quartet test is faulty. − B samples first show q = {i1, i2}, {i3, i4} and then P = min {B (q). − A samples show the probability that a single quartet test is faulty.

sections.heading: 14 Statistical Guarantee for the Tree Building Algorithm
sections.text: For a latent tree with d observed variables, the tree construction algorithm O (d log d) described in the essay requires calls to the quartet test method; the probability that the tree is wrongly constructed is limited by the probability that one of these quartet tests will yield incorrect results; that is P {The latent tree is misconstructed} ≤ P {Either one of the O (d log d) quartet tests returns an incorrect result} ≤ c · d log d · P {quartet test returns an incorrect result} (union-bound) ≤ 8c · d log d · e − mα 2 32, which implies that the probability of incorrectly constructing the tree decreases exponentially if we increase the number of samples m.

referenceMentions.context: Another family of provably consistent reconstruction methods is the quartet-based methods (Semple & Steel, 2003; Erdös et al., 1999).
Recently, (Anandkumar et al., 2011) proposed a quartet test using the leading k singular values of the joint probability table, where k is the number of hidden states.

Similar observations have been reported in the phylogenetic community (Eriksson, 2005; Allman & Rhodes, 2006), but they are concerned about the cases where the number of hidden states is larger or equal to the number of observed states.

Recently, (Anandkumar et al., 2011) proposed a quartet test using the leading k singular values of the joint probability table, where k is the number of hidden states. This new approach allows k to be different from the number of the observed states. However, it still requires k to be given in advance. Our goal is to design a latent structure discovery algorithm which is agnostic to the number of hidden states, since in practice we rarely know this number. The proposed approach is quartet based, where the quartet relations are resolved based on rank properties of 4th order tensors associated with the joint probability tables of quartets. The key insight is that rank properties of the tensor reveal the latent structure behind a quartet. Similar observations have been reported in the phylogenetic community (Eriksson, 2005; Allman & Rhodes, 2006), but they are concerned about the cases where the number of hidden states is larger or equal to the number of observed states. We focus instead on the cases where the number of hidden states is smaller, representing simpler factors. Furthermore, if the joint probability tensor is only approximately given (due to sampling noise) the main rank condition has to be modified. In Allman & Rhodes (2006) such condition is missing and in Eriksson (2005) the condition is heuristically translated to the distance of a matrix to its best rank-k approximation.

metadata.abstractText: Discovering the latent structure from many observed variables is an important yet challenging learning task. Existing approaches for discovering latent structures often require the unknown number of hidden states as an input. In this paper, we propose a quartet based approach which is agnostic to this number. The key contribution is a novel rank characterization of the tensor associated with the marginal distribution of a quartet. This characterization allows us to design a nuclear norm based test for resolving quartet relations. We then use the quartet test as a subroutine in a divide-and-conquer algorithm for recovering the latent tree structure. Under mild conditions, the algorithm is consistent and its error probability decays exponentially with increasing sample size. We demonstrate that the proposed approach compares favorably to alternatives. In a real world stock dataset, it also discovers meaningful groupings of variables, and produces a model that fits the data better.
